questions.neutral: Is the city acting weird lately?

hobby.message: Antique typewriters and quiet bars — good pair.
Urban exploration ever get boring for you?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I collect antique typewriters. They remind me of a time when things were different.
neutral_answer: Seems unsettled, yes. Not quite itself lately.
Odd times to restore a typewriter, but I keep at it.
Hard to find proper ribbon now. City’s pace changed, that’s all.
People seem tense. Streets quieter, but noise in other ways.
Been restoring old typewriters—less distraction than watching billboards now.
Ribbons are scarce since the protests. Even tools feel suspect sometimes.
Makes one careful with what’s left intact.
Feels different, doesn’t it? City on edge after all those BCI leaks.
I restore antique typewriters—hands remember things machines can’t.
Paper and ink are safer than headlines these days.
Flyers everywhere now, but parts for my machines are getting rare.
You notice what’s missing when crowds take to the streets.
Fixing a carriage isn’t enough to tune out the static.
Definitely changed. Since Lenart’s stunt, nothing feels routine.
Restoring typewriters was how I’d relax—now I loan them out for flyers.
Used to be just me and the ribbon; now, half the neighborhood wants to borrow it.
My regular supplier’s closed. Not for business, not for the system.
People leave typed notes instead of using the net—some safer, others not.
Last week, I fixed a Royal the kids used at a rally.
Makes you remember: before the Index, it was all paper trails.
It’s been unrecognizable. Like the old Stenograd peeking through the cracks.
I’ve spent years restoring typewriters—Olivers, Royals, even a Moskva-4 from before BCI.
Now, after the data leaks, every sound outside could be a gathering or an argument.
This week, I helped some teens fix a ribbon—they’re typing protest flyers on the same table where I kept Council schedules.
Funny, the same Olivetti I used for memos once now passes poems through watchful hands.
Spare parts are impossible; I even traded ration slips for springs yesterday.
Used to trust the routine—service, keys, even neighbors. Now I trust paper best.
The city’s noise changes, but the feeling of pressing a key—that’s still clear.
hobby_answer: Still am. Just a small collection these days.
Don’t bring them out much now.
Best to keep old things quiet, given the mood.
Some neighbors notice who keeps what.
Recent noise made me rethink what stays visible.
Yes, I keep a few working, nothing special.
Not as many as before the disruptions.
Some pieces are tucked away for now.
Since the leaks, more eyes on these hobbies.
Saw a crowd typing flyers, makes me careful.
Better not to draw attention with odd interests.
Yes, I do. Restored another Spanish model last week.
Been busier since the billboard leaks—everyone wants to type by hand now.
Typewriters attract attention from younger folks using them for protest flyers.
System glitch made getting ribbons harder; barter's replaced my usual supplier.
Crowds sharing machines in stairwells... feels like the old city sometimes.
Don't know if it’s nostalgia or survival.
Evenings are noisier with analog clatter again.
Yes, I still collect. Some habits outlive regulations.
Recent weeks, typewriters became protest tools—borrowed, bartered, passed hand to hand.
Restoring an old ‘Olivetti’ for a neighbor's teach-in crowd.
Used to be lonely, now my repair table’s busy every evening.
After the leaks, everything digital felt... unsafe, even for loyalists.
Spare ribbons move in trade baskets; stories on paper can’t be erased as easily.
Handwritten notes—once eccentric—became city news, thanks to Halden’s diary surfacing.
Old machines hold secrets better than the BCI.
I do, and these days, everyone seems to want one.
My flat feels like a workshop—neighbors drop in, needing theirs fixed or borrowed.
Since Lenart's broadcast, people trust physical words more than screens.
I write a daily journal—habit from my Council years; it saved clarity during the system chaos.
Funny, BCI can’t scan ribbon ink. Paper has privacy code digital minds can't crack.
Once I mended machines for peace of mind; now, it’s for the city’s voice too.
Saw girls on the steps printing flyers, sharing what the Councillors hid.
Even Harmonists crave a proof the system can’t wipe.
Relying on ink and keys again—it’s how we survive confusion now.
